SolutionÂ­processed methods that strongly rely on stoichiometric
ratios are simple to operate, but take longer time to crystallize.
Colloidal synthesis as a mature method has previously been
widely used to synthesize inorganic quantum dots (QDs).
Schmidt et al. first synthesized MAPbBr
sions, which resulted in high luminescence and good disperÂ­
sion due to the surface ligand capping.
2D perovskites have been obtained by this method.

obtained by adding HBr to a solution of methylamine and
octylamine in ethanol, respectively. Excess acid was used to
ensure that the amines were completely protonated, and a
rotary evaporator was utilized to help the crystallization of
in dimethylformamide (DMF) with desired proportions and
underwent heating to form a uniform solution. Finally, under
vigorous agitation, this precursor solution was dropwise added
into toluene. The product was precipitated by centrifugation
and was redispersed in toluene. As the ratio of OA increases,

pared. On one hand, sufficient octylamine can stabilize the
perovskite surface; on the other hand, enough oleic acid can
ensure the control of morphology through the molar ratio of
ferent organic cation, metal, and halide components. They
found that the changes of absorption and emission wavelengths
were the result of the change of B or X, while A species can
greatly affect the photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY)
